"What's wrong, boss?"
You: "This is a disaster!"
Your assistant: "What happened?"
You: "I don't know how it happened, but I somehow managed to delete my most important document!"
Your assistant: "Oh no!"

Your assistant: "Who do you want me to call?"
You: "I need you to call some companies that offer data recovery services. We need their help to recover my important document!"
Your assistant: "Sure, I'll get right on it!"

data.sampled: 'You can use a combination of regular expressions and the String.prototype.match() method to check if a value contains any of the strings in an array. For example: var arrayOfStrings = ['hello', 'world', 'hi', 'hey']; var myString = 'hello, world, hi'; var containsAll = myString.match(new RegExp(arrayOfStrings.join('|'), '.*')); if (containsAll) { alert('All strings in array are present in string.'); } else { alert('Some or no strings in array are present in string.'); } This example first joins all the strings in the array with '|' as a delimiter, and then passes it to match() along with a regular expression that matches any string containing this delimited string. The .* in the regular expression means that it must match at any position in the string (i.e. it can be at the beginning, middle, or end). Can this method be applied to more complex scenarios, for example, checking if a string contains all the words in an array? Yes, this method can be applied to more complex scenarios, such as checking if a string contains all the words in an array. The regular expression can be constructed dynamically based on the words in the array. For example: var arrayOfWords

data.sampled:
(n) an employee or agent who helps with important business or official duties;
There are times in a person’s career when it becomes necessary to hire an assistant.
The first time I did this, I felt like a complete idiot. I was in the middle of a big project and there was a great deal of paperwork and telephone calls that had to be made. I was trying to do everything myself and it was overwhelming.
One day, I found an advertisement in the local paper: “Assistant needed. Good salary. Great experience. Send resume to 555-1234.”
I thought, “I don’t even know what a ‘resume’ is. What the hell am I getting myself into?”
Nevertheless, I was desperate. I called and left a message on the answering machine.
Two days later, I received a call back.
The young lady who contacted me sounded very professional, but it took me a while to realize she was not talking to someone else.
I was embarrassed to be so ignorant about business.
She asked me if I would come in for an interview. I asked her what she meant. She said she wanted to see me in person for a few minutes, to get an idea of my personality, and make sure I was the right person for her company.
After I picked myself off the floor, we arranged a time that I could meet her. She was very accommodating.
When I arrived at her small office, she immediately asked me if I would please take off my cowboy hat.
I said, “What? Why?”
“Because it makes you look stupid.”
“Oh. Is that right?”
She said she would explain why later.
She gave me some paperwork to fill out, and I had to go to the restroom to do it because my eyes were getting blurry. I was so nervous I felt like I was taking a final exam.
When I finished

"You have been assigned to a 10-year-old child. How do you plan to approach this case with your patient?"
  • Behavioral: The patient is a 10-year-old child presenting for their first physical with you, and they are being accompanied by their mother. What is the first step you will take in your assessment?
  • Open-Ended: The patient is a 10-year-old child presenting for their first physical with you, and their mother is accompanying them. What questions do you have for the patient and/or mother to better understand the patient's medical history?
    • ``` In general, behavioral questions should focus on specific actions you would take in a given scenario, while open-ended questions allow for more open-ended responses and may require additional information to be effective.
